facts.text: The appellant is a private limited company formed under the Companies Act of 1956 to take over the assets and liabilities of another company as also its outstanding contracts.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is a private limited companypany, formed under the Companies Act of 1956, to take over the assets and liabilities of another companypany as also its outstanding companytracts.

facts.text: Predecessor company obtained a lease of considerable area of forest land in the North Andaman for exploiting timber.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that some time ago the predecessor companypany obtained a lease of a companysiderable area of forest land in the North Andaman with a view to exploiting its timber.

facts.text: Predecessor company chartered vessel Eastern Venture owned by Newland Steamship Co. Ltd. of Hongkong by charter-party executed in London on August 25,1954.

anchor.surface_text: One such vessel was Eastern Venture, owned by Newland Steamship Co. Ltd. of Hongkong, which the predecessor companypany hired by a charter-party executed in London on August 25,1954.

facts.text: Charter-party was uniform time charter for six months with option of another three months, renewed or extended from time to time.

facts.text: Terms of charter-party of August 25,1954 continued in force with slight modification.

facts.text: Clause 6: Charterers to pay hire 16s. per ton on 5,250 tons per 30 days in advance in cash in Calcutta.

arguments.claim: Payments not chargeable as earmarking for expenditure irrelevant

anchor.surface_text: it is one of the fundamental principle of income-tax law that one cannot determine for income-tax purposes the nature of a payment by inquiring what becomes of it or what must become of it after the payee has received it.

holdings.text: The advances made under clause 14 of the charter-party were not loans but pre-payments of portions of the hire.

anchor.surface_text: For all the above reasons, I am of opinion that the advances made in the present case were number loan, but pre-payments, of portions of the hire

holdings.reasoning_summary: Construction of clause 14 allowing deduction from hire indicates pre-payment; interest provision is rebate for prepayment; supported by shipping law precedents like Allison v. Bristol Marine Insurance Co. and Mansfield v. Maitland.

holdings.text: Even assuming the advances were loans initially, they were repaid in Calcutta by deduction from the hire due to the ship owners, constituting constructive receipt by the non-resident owners in India.

anchor.surface_text: that even assuming that they were loans, that character borne by them initially is immaterial... they were repaid in Calcutta by deduction from the hire due to the ships owners

holdings.reasoning_summary: Deduction from hire payable in India applies owners' money to repayment; cannot repay with own money; cites Keshav Mills Ltd. v. CIT.

holdings.text: The payments (disbursements as pre-payments of hire) were amounts chargeable under the provisions of the Income-tax Act within the meaning of section 18(3B), as 'chargeable' means liable to be brought into computation under one of the heads of income in section 6, including gross receipts.

anchor.surface_text: if the word chargeable was taken to mean number assessable to tax, but as liable in its nature to be brought into companyputation in an assessment, that is to say, as belonging to one or other of the heads of income, as set out in section 6 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction with s18(3C) allowing proportion for gross sums; SC in Aggarwal Chamber of Commerce Ltd. v. Ganpat Rai Hiralal confirms deductions on gross without regard to net taxability.

holdings.text: Even if advances were part-payments of hire, they were chargeable under s18(3B) as gross receipts liable under s6 heads, not requiring net taxable income determination.

anchor.surface_text: The next of Mr. Mitras companytention was that even assuming that the advances made to the ships master were part-payments of the hire, they were yet number chargeable under the provisions of the Indian Income-tax Act

holdings.reasoning_summary: 'Chargeable' includes gross under s6; s18(3C), SC precedent on agency ss40(2),42(1); English precedents like Nielsen Anderson.

holdings.text: Payments earmarked for ordinary disbursements were still chargeable as income under the Act; nature determined at receipt, irrespective of subsequent expenditure or earmarking.

anchor.surface_text: The third companytention was that, in any event, the payments in the present case had been made for ordinary disbursements on the vessels account and, therefore, the amounts companycerned were clearly earmarked for expenditure.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fundamental principle of IT law: receipt's character fixed on receipt, not subsequent use; cites Commissioners of Inland Revenue v. Corporation of London as Conservators of Epping Forest.

holdings.text: The Income-tax Officer's letter of March 17, 1956 is a speaking order disclosing reasons (constructive receipt), amenable to certiorari for errors of law on face of record; however, no such error exists.

anchor.surface_text: As it has been otherwise expressed, the order, alleged to be vitiated by the error, must be a speaking order, that is to say, an error giving its reasons for the view taken therein and such reasons being manifestly wrong.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Letter states constructive receipt basis for s18(3B)/ (7); speaking orders reviewable per modern scope of certiorari (Rex v. Northumberland); merits correct as above.

holdings.text: Writ of certiorari will not issue due to pendency of alternative statutory appeal preferred by appellant without disclosure to court, demonstrating lack of candor and disingenuous conduct.

anchor.surface_text: In my opinion, quite apart from the fact that the appellant was disingenuous with the trial companyrt, the pendency of an appeal preferred by it against the same order would be sufficient reason

holdings.reasoning_summary: Alternative remedy not absolute bar but discretion against writ when pursued simultaneously without candor; cites Rashid & Sons v. IT Investigation Commission, Rex v. Inspector of Taxes.

precedents.citation: Commissioners of Inland revenue v. Corporation of London

anchor.surface_text: the decision in Commissioners of Inland revenue v. Corporation of London. The points ultimately argued were thus the three I have indicated. Before proceeding to deal with the companytentions of Mr. Mitra, it will be companyvenient to read section 18 3B  of the Act.

precedents.case_name: Commissioners of Inland Revenue v Corporation of London
precedents.cited_proposition: Expression 'annual payment' excludes mere trading receipts requiring deduction of expenses to determine taxable income

precedents.citation: allison v. Bristol Marine Insurance Co.

anchor.surface_text: the decision of the house of Lords in the case of allison v. Bristol Marine Insurance Co. The question whether an advance made by a charter to the ships master for ordinary disbursements is a loan or a part-payment of the freight is of importance number for taxing purposes alone, but for another vital purpose as well.

precedents.case_name: Allison v Bristol Marine Insurance Co
precedents.cited_proposition: Advance to master for disbursements may be prepayment of freight despite interest provision, as rebate for prepayment
precedents.cited_holding: Provision for interest does not necessarily make advance a loan but can be rebate for prepayment

anchor.surface_text: the observations of some of the learned Judges in the well- known case of Manfreld v. Maitland. That was a case where one-half of the freight was to be paid in cash on unloading and right delivery of the cargo and the remainder by bill on London at four months date and then the charter-party provided that the captain was to be supplied with case for the ships use.

precedents.cited_proposition: Absence of deduction provision means advance is loan; presence indicates part-payment of freight

precedents.cited_proposition: Money applied in India on behalf of non-resident under instruction is received in India

anchor.surface_text: The supervision by means of the writ of certiorari goes, as the Privy Council observed in the case of Rex. v.
